raw_text:
1. An Umberto Eco essay on one author's "Narrative Structures" claims this character always "mates in eight moves." This man's scrambled eggs recipe appears in a story named for him "in New York." This man is the protagonist of Colonel Sun, a novel ghostwritten by Kingsley Amis, who wrote a book subtitled "Every Man His Own" [this character] under the pseudonym Bill Tanner. This man coldly notes the suicide of a woman working for (*) SMERSH, Vesper Lynd, and foils a gang of lesbian burglars' plan to steal from Fort Knox. This character's wife is murdered by Ernst Stavro Blofeld, the leader of SPECTRE, in the book On Her Majesty's Secret Service. For 10 points, Ian Fleming created which spy, designated 007?
ANSWER: James Bond [accept Agent 007 until read; accept 007 in New York until "007" is read; accept The Book of Bond; or Every Man His Own 007] (The essay is "Narrative Structures in Fleming.") <Jamie Burchett, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29763~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson> NSC 2025 - Round 25 (Extras) - Bonuses

This man's scrambled eggs recipe appears in a story named for him "in New York." This man is the protagonist of Colonel Sun, a novel ghostwritten by Kingsley Amis, who wrote a book subtitled "Every Man His Own" [this character] under the pseudonym Bill Tanner.
This man coldly notes the suicide of a woman working for (*) SMERSH, Vesper Lynd, and foils a gang of lesbian burglars' plan to steal from Fort Knox.
This character's wife is murdered by Ernst Stavro Blofeld, the leader of SPECTRE, in the book On Her Majesty's Secret Service.
For 10 points, Ian Fleming created which spy, designated 007?

ANSWER: James Bond [accept Agent 007 until read; accept 007 in New York until "007" is read; accept The Book of Bond; or Every Man His Own 007] (The essay is "Narrative Structures in Fleming.") <Jamie Burchett, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~29763~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson> NSC 2025 - Round 25 (Extras) - Bonuses

raw_text:
1. A "Farewell to" this place bids "Adieu, the flow’ry plain" and asks "Why, Phoebus, moves thy car so slow?" upon the author’s journey to "Britannia." For 10 points each: 
[10m] Name this place, the second title location of a poem that declares "‘Twas mercy brought me from my Pagan land." A poem to "his excellency," a leader of this place, begins "Celestial choir! enthron’d in realms of light." 
ANSWER: America [accept "A Farewel To America. To Mrs. S. W."; accept "On Being Brought from Africa to America"] (The poem is "His Excellency General Washington.")
[10e] This author wrote "On Being Brought from Africa to America" in her Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral. 
ANSWER: Phyllis Wheatley [or Phillis Wheatley Peters]
[10h] The first poem in Poems on Various Subjects is addressed to this man "beneath the myrtle shade." In a footnote to that poem to this man, Wheatley notes that Terence was an African by birth. 
ANSWER: Maecenas [accept "To Maecenas"]
<Jaimie Carlson, Literature - American - Poetry> ~25541~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson>
